Babaloo, I did just that. After 15+ years and trips to the region, I finally decided to take my money elsewhere several years ago after a visit to the RM and the town of PDC. Shakedowns, scams on the streets by vendors, being ripped off at gas stations, being insulted by vendors when you do not stop at their store...I decided to take my money elsewhere. Shame really, some very nice people and beautiful areas but throw in all the scams with the drug violence, it was time to go elsewhere. I am not scared, just annoyed and feel other places/people are more deserving of my business.

#18 You make sense. You were not happy visiting Mexico so instead of telling the world how bad that you thought it was you decided to go elsewhere. I think that shows intelligence. No one has a tag on their toe that says go to Mexico or else. Places change. What at one time appealed to some no longer appeals. No reason to bad mouth it, just go somewhere else or find a nice place close to home.Personally, I still enjoy both sides of Mexico.

Agree wholeheartedly with post 14! We need to protect society (ourselves) from those who don’t believe in this pandemic, are too poor or ignorant to comply, or simply too arrogant to comply. As we know, compliance and enforcement in some areas of the US and in Canada and EU has been very effective, and tourist areas like the Riviera Maya need an even higher level of compliance and enforcement for public safety...I’m reading that the highest infection area of Cancun is in the nortH among local residents. Joan if that is accurate, is there evidence yet that these people work around tourists and the spread started there? Or is the spread mainly in the tourist areas?

Bluewater, I'm not sure what you mean by accurate evidence but I can tell you the areas that have the highest infections are all areas where housing is small and generally cheaper than other areas. As a result, it a VERY popular area for resort workers and restaurant wait staff to live. There's no way to know whether these workers brought it into the hotel zone with it whether they took it home with them after interaction with tourists at their places of work. My guess would be it's a little of each. And unfortunately, these are areas where there's a high instance of people not wearing masks. And in fairness, it should be pointed out that once at work and masked, they are around unmasked tourists all the time as many resorts do not require them after check in. I have a good friend who runs a taqueria where the buses pick up employees to take them to work. His customers are probably 90% resort workers and they've told him that practicality every day someone shows up to work with a fever. Each resort handles that differently but clearly there's an issue. Who's bringing g it to who though is the million dollar question. Like I said, I believe it's a little of both.
